description: From Middle English felt, from Old English felt, from Proto-West Germanic *felt (compare Dutch vilt, German Filz, Danish filt, French feutre), from Proto-Indo-European *pilto, *pilso 'felt' (compare Latin pilleus (“felt”, adjective), Old Church Slavonic плъсть (plŭstĭ), Albanian plis, Ancient Greek πῖλος (pîlos)), from *pel- 'to beat'. More at anvil.

entries.meaning: A cloth or stuff made of matted fibres of wool, or wool and fur, fulled or wrought into a compact substance by rolling and pressure, with lees or size, without spinning or weaving.

examples: You'll notice that all the illustrations are done in different media: some with pencil crayons, some with felts, some with paint, some with chalk pastels.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A skin or hide; a fell; a pelt.

verbs.description: felt (third-person singular simple present felts, present participle felting, simple past and past participle felted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make into felt, or a feltlike substance; to cause to adhere and mat together.
(transitive) To cover with, or as if with, felt.
examples: to felt the cylinder of a steam engine

entries.meaning: (transitive, poker) To cause a player to lose all their chips.

description: Old English fēled, corresponding to feel +‎ -ed.

adjectives.description: felt (comparative more felt, superlative most felt)

entries.meaning: That has been experienced or perceived.
examples: Conversions to Islam can therefore be a deeply felt aesthetic experience that rarely occurs in Christian accounts of conversion, which are generally the source rather than the result of a Christian experience of beauty.

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of feel
